Painted Ladies.name: Painted Ladies

address.streetAddress: Alamo Square, Steiner and Hayes Sts.

reviews: Fun to do but wouldn't go out of my way...

We really enjoyed standing in nearby Alamo Park and looking at the different views of the city from the top of the hill. San Francisco is a city filled with beautiful victorian homes and the painted ladies were very nice, but there are plenty of other examples and neighborhoods that are much more interesting. If you were a Full House fan as a kid, then you definitely want to see this.
Show less
Higher expectations, but not sue why...

The houses are gorgeous being older Victorian homes. But finding out that the Full House 'house' isn't amongst then kinda puts a damper on the visit. Being a 90s kid, there was a bunch of nostalgia with this visit that wasn't really met. Still worth checking out but don't waste much of your day here.
Show less
Just go for a quick stop

You don't need more than 5 minutes to get your pics but walk up a few mins in to Alamo Park and you will get a great picture of the city too. There's nothing else to do other than photo a few houses...

Did you ever watch Full House as a kid? If so do you remember the intro of the show where you saw the row of colorful homes? The Painted Ladies of Alamo Square are 7 homes that were in the intro for Full House. Just in front of it is Alamo Square Park. The park is so nice and cute, there are coffee vendors so you can grab something to drink/eat and go park yourself on a bench and take in the views. The park is up on a hill, the is a playground for kids, plenty of grassy area to bring a blanket and have a picnic. Dogs are allowed to play around as well. Wish we had a park like this where we live- would be spending a lot of time there if we did!
Show less

There really isn't much to say about the Painted Ladies other than "cute". We spent about 5 minutes there, and that seemed like an eternity. The views of the city skyline was much more pleasing than the views of the houses. Not something to go out of your way to see, but if in the area it's worth a quick visit.
Show less

As an avid fan of early 90s tv, the ‘Full House’ Houses had to be on my list of things to see during my trip to San Francisco. My British husband didn’t quite get it but happily went along with me. They didn’t disappoint for the full 5 minutes we were there. Go if it’s on the way but don’t travel hours just for a glimpse and as it’s catty corner to a high school perhaps time your visit so you aren’t in a hoard of high schoolers?
Show less

This location is easy to find. I would suggest maybe stopping here towards the before sunset portion of your day. With all the walking done in SF it was nice to have this be our final stop and just relax and enjoy the view from the park.
Show less
Great spot to take pics. Parking somewhat limited. There’s a park across the street with a few nice playgrounds and restrooms. Eve restrooms aren’t so clean but they work.
Going to SF you must visit the Painted Ladies. The alamo Square park (in front of the houses) is also a nice attraction. People walk with their dogs, do pic nics, etc.
I can get some of the Skyline in the pic
You can get a pic of the painted ladies with a part of the San Francisco Skyline which is awesome. It's to far to walk from the financial district to the painted ladies but it's worth coming anyways.
Pretty. If you have a short amount of time in SF this is something I would suggest you skip. They do line a beautiful park. It was nice to walk and see the many dogs playing.
Iconic houses of SF well worth a look

We headed here on our way out to the airport and glad we did. The houses are beautiful and such a part of San Francisco's architecture (a review further on describes the Painted Ladies perfectly).

Great photo opportunity and the skyline looking back is lovely too (even on our overcast day!)
Show less
Cute little strip of houses, kids thought it was cool we visited

My husband and I stopped by here during a short trip to SF. We knew it was really just a short street of Victorian houses, which wouldn't normally attract us to visit. But both our girls have grown up watching reruns of Full House and the most recent Fuller House so we had to swing by for a quick photo opt. We sent our teenager a selfie of us and the houses and she about died, she loved it. If you grew up watching Full House or your kids enjoy the show, it's worth a quick stop just for the visual coolness. If not, you could probably skip it as there isn't really anything else there besides a large park that locals seem to bring their dogs to.
Show less
Only a very quick photo opportunity required

If you haven't got much time then you won't have missed much, but if you have spare time then these seven differently painted houses in a row, with a fantastic backdrop of the Financial District do make for a great picture (id it's not overcast as it was the day we went).
Show less
Nice houses. Nothing fantastic have a look whilst in the area they are famous but wouldn’t go out of my way to see them again

Beautiful Victorian homes are a must see as a part of SFO history. Architecture is amazing and breathtaking. They are beautifully cared for and worth a visit.

There is a man who is selling art/photographs of the painted Ladies at Pier one. (I think on Saturdays and Sundays.) He takes the photos and then pixelates them. Beautiful work and beautiful soul.
Show less

It takes a bit of effort to get there; like a lot of places in San Francisco, you have to go up and down a lot to finally get to your intended destination. This time, the whole ups and down didn't really seem to worth it. The row of painted houses are known for their unique architecture but to me a lot of houses and neighborhood in San Francisco seem to share the same appearance. I probably do not have the fine taste in architecture to understand the uniqueness of them. On the plus side, you get a great city view from this location
Show less
Maybe this is a case where the picture is better than the actual sight. The houses are iconic. But to really get the full breath of the painted ladies genre take a look at the Painted Ladies book.

The view from this park is fabulous. I was excited to finally see the houses but I hadn't realized how great the view of the city was going to be. We did the hop on hop off bus tour and this is a walk of a couple of blocks to get to the park.
Show less
Visit the neighborhood and make sure to visit Alamo Square park for a view of the painted ladies and San Francisco Skyrises.
The houses are nice but not worth the headache of finding parking or making a special trip for. The area is surrounded by tourists and buses

We just purchased a town house in Calgary Canada which is modeled after the SFO Painted Ladies.......so had to go and visit the originals. Worth the Uber ride out to the Filmore area, while there walk through the Filmore area and have coffee.
Charming row of houses, out of standard design you find from the area. Journey to get there was more interesting.
Got their name from from being painted in three or more colors

We visited the “painted ladies” during our city tour with Dylan’s Tours.

They were built in Victorian or Edwardian style depending on which year they were constructed, and get their name from being painted in three or more colors to enhance their architectural details.

It is believed that there were 48,000 houses in the Victorian and Edwardian styles were built in San Francisco between 1849 and 1915. Many of these style homes in Nob Hill were destroyed by the 1906 San Francisco earthquake, but there are thousands of houses that did survive the earthquake.

Beautiful historical buildings well worth viewing.
Show less

There are some cool houses in San Francisco, if that's what you're into, perhaps this is a highlight for you. For the rest of us-this is just a few houses. San Francisco is huge, don't spend time looking for these when there are so many other cool things to see and do.
Show less
Enjoyed seeing them on a bus tour!
Exactly how I think neighbourhoods should be, colourful and attractive! These buildings are lovely and a pleasure to see. Not worth walking to I don’t think but was nice to pass by :-)

So pleased we made time in our 3-day visit to San Fran to see the Painted Ladies.
As with most historic sites, we knew some of these buildings' history and present-day context, and our visit was enriched by that.
Over the road, there's a lovely park for a stroll, with children's play area and The Lady Falcon coffee bus: delicious coffee served by lovely people.
Easy access to the area by public transport.
Hints: learn a little of Painted Ladies' history / try to visit before mid-morning, as it can get busy later in the day, especially at weekends if good weather. Chill out with a coffee at Lady Falcon.
Show less

The Painted Ladies are Victorian styled townhouses which have been restored structurally and painted in bright colors, some would say gaudy colors.

Whatever, they’re a symbol of San Francisco just as is the Golden Gate Bridge.

Hard to believe but the Ladies are said to have been painted in Battleship Gray, I.e. Haze Gray, after WWII because the Navy had a lot of surplus paint. Or so the story goes.

From the street, you have a view not only of the Houses but down to City Hall and downtown.
Show less

The pictures of this block of Victorian houses are ubiquitous and closely associated with the commonly known view of the city.
There are 1000's of these rows in San Francisco but these ones are famous because of the backdrop.
While there are better ones these are the famous painted ladies and I add my couple of photos into the mix.
1972
Show less
Lots of people here taking photos. most stayed back but some had to be right up front getting in everyone else's pics.

As others have mentioned, watch out for car break-ins while visiting this popular tourist spot. SF has a lot of crime and bums - our rental car was broken into during the middle of the day and I'm convinced that someone the area acts as a lookout.
Show less

We cycled here and it was so hilly. The hills kill us.

But once you are here, sit in the park for a while and view the city. The 7 painted sisters/ladies are beautiful and with the SF in the background, it is a feast for the eyes.
Show less

Be prepared to walk a ways to get up close and take some good photos. As others have suggested, I would do this on a guided tour. It’s tough to find parking in this area and it’s rife with tourists. That being said, if you don’t go you’ll probably regret it because of the iconic photos you’ll miss out on!
Show less
Make This a Part of a Guided Tour

There are several choices in guided tours of the San Francisco area. Most include these homes as part of their agenda. While famous, there are many other homes to see in the city. Walking tours of special areas are a great investment.
The "Painted Ladies" are a row of historical houses on a hill just outside the downtown area of San Francisco - on the perimeter of a park. There are great views of the city.
If you are on car rental, dont park at the Hayes/Pierce St area... or any area not visible as you visit the park.

After staying less than 15 mins in the park, we went back to our car (rental) parked at the Hayes St near Pierce St. From about 300 meters from the car, i saw a guy looking through our car windows. A black car was idling at the opposite lane... obviously the getaway car. We didnt leave anything on the car seats and there were no valuables in the car but i saw the guy raising his arm and about to break our window. I screamed on the guy from the distance and he immediately ran towards the black car and sped away. They didnt get anything but these guys ruined our awesome San Francisco experience.
Show less

The houses use to be painted different colors and many a poster shows them that way but now they are all painted the same of neutral color and are very bland to the eye; however, the view of the city from the hill is worth the trip. It is a short cab ride or uber. Great for a picnic on the grass or flying your drone which is how techies fly kites. If your looking for something that is up lifting and not to stressful, give this a go. Basically, these are just four houses that look a like in a row, Don't expect anything more.
Show less
It was fun to walk down Steiner Street to see the painted ladies. So much history and beautiful architecture to admire.
ALamo Square and the victorian ladies perfection and beauty to our eyes.I enjoyed my time there. I highly recommend to visit them.

If you visit San Francisco there are a few things you must see and the Painted Ladies are one of them. The pleasing colors, the architecture, the way they were built on the hillside...a side trip worth viewing.
Really nice to see on a sunny day! Easily accessible with public transport. And a nice little park across the road to sit on the grass or entertain the kids on the playground! Go and see!
A must see in San Francisco if you have a car.

Check this one off the bucket list. As I wrote in my Alamo Square review, these houses are very pretty, but so are other ones on the main streets surrounding Alamo Square. What sets these particular six houses apart are that they are all in a row and have an open background behind them which makes for nice pictures!
Show less
If you don't do this as part of a tour, just grab a lyft there. Easy to get to, and a great spot for pictures.
See all of SF houses, not just these

The Painted Ladies are an iconic part of SF. So you really must go and see them. The views from the hill just across for them are fantastic so you get more than just a view of some houses.

But, there are much nicer houses all around San Francisco. Not just these. So absolutely go visit the painted ladies but take some time to just visit some regular houses too. They are all beautiful!
Show less
Only if you are a Full House fan
There is a park on a hill, tourists taking photos of the row of houses, and not much more. Sorry, we were not impressed.

Love visiting the painted ladies. Yes it's just a row of houses but it is a classic and a SF must see. Now that Alamo Square park is back open you can enjoy the painted ladies even more from a shady spot atop the hill.
Underwhelming - walk around and see more beautiful houses

We were quite underwhelmed when we eventually got to the painted ladies as the houses looked like they needed a refresh. There are plenty more beautiful and colourful streets with houses just like this all over the city with views that are even more amazing!

We would recommend walking around / getting lost and coming across some nicer parts of San Fran
Show less
This place is one of the nicest places in SF. I think every visitor of SF should come to see them. THough I expected there would be more of them:)
I know the Painted Ladies are only a row of houses but they are just so San Francisco!!! Have seen them on each of my four visit to the city and still find the beautiful.

I've always wanted to see these it person, and I finally did. The 30 year anniversary of the release of Full House was this month, so I wanted to stop by and see these. They are beautiful, but there are other homes in the neighborhood that are just as beautiful.
Show less

The park is quite nice, lots of room to sit and walk. The views are good but not the best in the city. The location is fairly far from the downtown (Union Square), but $10-$15 uber. The houses are cool and make a nice picture. I never really watched Full House so didn't have a culture significance to me. Still worth an afternoon or a couple hours if you are in the city for more than 3 days.
Show less

the houses upclose are beautiful and the current owners have maintained them very well, they are occupied so try no to disturb the homeowners, theres a park infront where you can see them from afar and take great pics.
The Painted Ladies - Most Famous SF Homes
Drive by - pop out and take a photo - of this cadre of painted Victorian Homes...Unique - and fun to see - sicne youve seen them in TV adsadn TV shows forever

I wanted to visit after a childhood growing up with Full House so a bit of a novelty visit.
This is a bit of trek on foot as there isnt really anything else around and a bit far from the main part of town.
But photo worthy none the less.
Show less
Not a whole heap to do here but walk past and take a picture. It gets quite busy and we were fortunate enough to get a car park but plan on having to park and walk.

While San Francisco is full of beautiful architecture, the immaculate presentation of these homes along with the stunning skyline of San Francisco in the background makes them worth a visit . Sitting in the park opposite, you won't be the only one loading your "Full House" pics to social media.
We caught the number 21 bus out from the middle of town and it was a very easy ride - about 12 minutes. The buses seem to run fairly frequently in both directions .
Show less

Lovely neighbourhood filled with old victorian/edwardian houses. Lovely to walk around and admire the beautiful architecture. Finally made it to Alamo Sq where the painted ladies are located. Beautiful place.

Although we visited on a record breaking hot day in SF, it was well worth the visit.

The Painted Ladies, a set of exquisitely preserved Victorian houses, sit just off Alamo Square and they are like the postcards. It's my second favourite SF scene after the Golden Gate Bridge.

Alamo Square itself is a a lovely Park and lots of people were out picnicking. It also offers stunning views over SF right down to City Hall.

Go visit!
Show less

This was pretty boring for anyone not familiar with Full House. The park is nice, but not a real stop-worthy experience. Maybe if there were a tour of the buildings, it would be better. Won't be planning to go back unless driving by.

Very pretty area in general. Would have loved to spend more time at the park and walking around the neighborhood. Parking is limited during certain hours so I'd check before you go. Great stop in my opinion.
We were in the area and deliberately walked past, whilst they are lovely, San Fransisco has many streets with great and well maintained Victorian houses. Good park across the road for best views.
When we went it was great weather took a couple of pics then sat on the grass for a bit would have been good for a picnic wouldn't have been so nice in the rain
These houses are pretty, but in my opinion, overrated. If you have limited time, I wouldn't put them at the top.

There is not that much to see but it is a historic landmark so I guess in that aspect it makes it worth a stop. I prefer the park that the ladies face more as it has a nice view of the city. It's clean and you can lounge around or even have a picnic there.
Show less

Pretty houses that are easy to get to (on Alamo Square) with easy on street parking. They are worth seeing but there is not much else to do once you've seen them - we drove to them as part of another journey and I think this is the best way to see them.
Show less

The downtown views are great in the background. Don’t miss that part. Usually the tourist crowd take pictures of the houses and leave. But wait for the sun to go down to see the downtown when the building lights come on. The views are spectacular! If you need the address to visit this place, get to Steiner St, San Francisco and you will not miss to spot the Victorian style houses.
Show less

If you ever are in San Francisco, and if you're an 80's baby who grew up watching Full House then you absolutely have to head down to Steiner Street (opposite Alamo Park) for a glimpse of the Painted Ladies - the iconic Victorian houses (characteristic of San Francisco) that were featured in the cult 80's sitcom, which was also where the fictional Tanner family resided (of course, back then, the house was off-white and had a red door). It doesn't take too long to get there, and it's pretty centrally located. You'll be able to catch a view of the whole row of colorfully painted houses from the small park (Alamo Park) across the street. Do note that these houses are privately owned, so please don't get too close or even trespass. Rumour has it that the creator and executive producer of the show Jeff Franklin owns the house that was meant to be the Tanner Household.
Show less

First of all, to appreciate these six houses, you must have at least a slight understanding of the history behind it (go to wikipedia or just google painted ladies and there's a lot of write ups about it). Other than that, you go to Alamo Square (just a park across the street) for best view point. To the right is one ugly big building, and to the left sits another older Victorian house that the original designer and builder once lived. Yes, the designer builder that built all six Painted Ladies used to live in the house on the left. Other than that, read up a little on Victorian architecture first to gain more understanding.

Neighbourhood wise, it's not super safe. But then again, I've being warned by local people, that theft really target tourist cars around that place, by breaking into cars and stealing things, just anythings. So be careful.
Show less
... but you don't have to see them... I went there on purpose... nice to see. The view from ALamo square is nice though.
Good for a quick visit to say you saw the iconic houses

It's a nice place to stop and you can do it in a half hour or less. We circled Alamo Square Park a couple times, as parking was tough. Just look a few blocks away and you should find some street parking. There weren't that many people when we visited on a cloudy Thursday morning, so that was nice. Tourists get so excited over the houses, and you will see tons of giggling girls.
Show less
Of course, if you grew up on Full House, these are iconic. Not much to do here though. If you walk up the hill opposite the houses, it's a pretty great view.
We visited the Painted Ladies because my daughter wanted to see them. People think that one of the houses is where Full House was recorded.
Painted Ladies - Seven Sisters - Full House Opening Credits

The painted Ladies are seven Victorian homes that are an iconic image of San Francisco immortalized in the opening credits of the shows Full House and Fuller House.they are right across from the Alamo Park where the picnic scene for the opening credits was filmed and a mile away from 1709 Broaderick which was the Tanner Family house. We went on a weekday at 2 pm so there wasn't a lot of traffic and we could take pictures.
Show less
Better if you don't visit on a weekend.

Beautiful houses in an iconic setting. When Alamo Square Park is full on weekends, it gets harder to take pictures without people in them (and much harder to find parking).
Once you have seen the houses, there really isn't a reason to return to see them again.
We visited twice as we had friends that wanted to see the houses. Fortunately they were able to visit during the week. They were done with the ladies after 5 minutes.
Street parking can fill up fast.
So many other places to visit in the city, this is not on our list of must see attractions.
Show less

A bit isolated from the "heart" of San Francisco. They are a nice set of homes but other than a quick glance and taking a few pics, not much to see. The park across the street (filmed in opening of Full House) looks like a decent sized park but parking wasn't available when we went so didn't get a chance to see. Worth going if In area but personally wouldn't go out of your way.
Show less
Nice to glance at, not a lot else to see!

This area is a little isolated and other than stopping to take a photo of these houses or have a rest on the grassy bank opposite, there is little else to see or do. We did, however, note free wifi in the park which as useful!

I'm sure the homeowners must get quite annoyed with the number of tourists stood opposite taking photos.

Unless you are really interested, perhaps give it a miss.
Show less
Beautiful historic houses next to a park on a hill. Nice place to stop and rest and take in the views.

The Painted Ladies are easily seen from a short walk through Alamo Square. Some people brought picnics and sat around the grass areas; others walked through for a quick picture in front of the known houses. The area is easily accessible and tourist friendly.
Came here via cab, ok for a few photos, opposite a small park with kids playground.with quite a lot of tourist still not a lot to see.
Good but construction work in the park

At the end of the day this is a row of old houses in pastel colours. I felt we had to visit this famous location on our trip and was pleasantly surprised by the view. It was a beautiful day too but sadly the park opposite had construction work going on which somewhat compromised the view.
Show less

The "middle class" Victorian homes made famous by the Full House show are there to behold in their full splendor. Lovely stop on a tour. Tip if you go to the top of th e hill you'll catch a nice photo of the houses with the San Francisco skyline in the background.
Show less

Houses were on our list bit disappointed with the houses as not as many as I thought but worth a visit .to be fair it was overcast so if the sun was out and you could sit and have a picnic it woyld be nice

You have probably seen this iconic set of buildings in 90's shows like Full House. A collection of beautiful architecture.

It's a "nice to see once" kind of thing, and I wouldn't go out of my way to see them, but if you're close by give it a go.
Show less
A touristy attraction, but a nice place to sit and relax

Alamo Square is a great place to plant yourself on the grass and take a few photos of the painted ladies. The parking around here is pretty easy to deal with on the street, and the houses are well manicured and worthy of a few photos.
Show less
Cool view and great park / playground
Great sunny day out in July at the playground opposite the painted ladies. It's worth an Uber up to this area and then a walk down Hayes St as it's a cool neighbourhood.

We took a Lyft to see the Painted Ladies when visiting San Francisco. We went in the evening. It was one of the coolest things we did in SF. First of all the Lyft dropped us off and there are lots of people in the park across the street all reenacting the picnic scene from Full House. As the fog started to roll in the park was a beautiful place to be. It was like standing in a cloud. We walked all around. It was just such a beautiful part of San Francisco to see.
Show less
Worth seeing once, but that's it

These homes are iconic for the city are beautifully restored. They have been featured on TV and movies so if you're into that sort of thing, it's cool to go and say you've been there. You get a nice view of downtown San Francisco as well. I've been there, seen it, won't return if we're ever in the city again, however.
That said, parking is Very hard to find. Alamo Square park is directly across the street from the Painted Ladies and it's a nice little park to have a picnic, take a nap on a blanket, or just hang out with family or friends....which is what most everyone was doing. You'll need to climb some stairs to get up off the street and up to the grassy area. There's a dog park up over the hill as well. The bathrooms are nightmarishly filthy...yuck.
Show less

It was the strangest thing..the tour bus said to get off at this park and see these houses so we did. Tons of people were picnicking and staring at these houses. It was really weird. There was nothing special about these houses. I don't get it. I feel sorry for the people who live there having people staring into their front windows all day. They aren't even painted brightly. We have these kind of houses in every historical city. Am I missing something?
Show less

My family of four (kids aged 10 and 12) came here after our arrival on a long flight. We had time before we could check into our AirBnB so we made a stop here. We were lucky enough to find a parking spot directly across the street from the houses, on the park side. The park was teeming with like-minded people taking their own pictures of these iconic houses.

We posed, took pictures, and used the bathrooms (gross but usuable) at the playground. The kids played for a few minutes at the playground but it was really for younger children. Beautiful views of the city and the TransAmerica Pyramid from the park.

I had read numerous reports here about car break-ins and thefts. Luckily, we were not affected, but take the crime problem into consideration if you decide to visit.
Show less
Been there, don't feel like I need to go back

I have grown up visiting San Fran but have never made it to this iconic spot. The park across the street is Alamo Square which has great views of the Painted Ladies and is a good spot to take pics. They are beautiful and worth a stop but I don't feel like I need to go back for future visits.
Show less
Up to 70 car break ins PER DAY!!! Don't leave a car unattended!

Totally anticlimactic and VERY unsafe location. We parked for 15 minutes in front of over 100 tourists taking pictures, and our window was smashed and my 10 year old son's backpack was stolen with his lifelong favorite stuffed Curious George. Police say there can be up to 70 break ins PER DAY in that area. We saw 3 in the hour we dealt with our issue.

TOURISTS AVOID!!!!!
Show less

Very easy to find and visit, you can park and hang at the public park across the street and get some great views. Both of the city and the painted ladies. The houses look phenomenal and you can see them without getting that one theme song in your head, you know the one!!
Show less
These old Victorian & Edwardian houses look simply stunning. They are familiar from various TV series & films and might be the most photographed sight in SFO. Just check them out.

I know they are pretty iconic when you think of the city, thanks to their appearance in numerous films and TV shows but they sadly werent really that interesting in person. We saw them whilst on the hop on hop off bus tour and didn't actually bother getting off the bus as they are simply some painted buildings, not even very unique to be honest. If your interested in the film locations angle then great, but I don't think they are worth making the effort to see if you are tight on time in the city
Show less

Well, I know that Painted ladies on Steiner St is probably one of the most featured, most popular and dearest landmarks of SF. But, to me, it's just 7 houses painted in different colours.

But however if we visit SF, again, our visit wouldn't be complete if you do not visit these seven victorian houses. But, once is enough.And try to dig some historical backround and fun facts about it prior to your visit.

15 minutes is just enough to enjoy and photograph painted ladies unless you wanna do picnic on Alamo Square which is right in front of the houses. A public toilet is located in the square. But it's not that clean. If you travel with kids, and your kids are not into the houses, just take them to the play ground at Alamo Square.

For tourists who come with big tourist buses, normally bus will drop you off & pick you up at the intersection of Fell St & Pierce St. Then, you have to walk up to the right at Pierce St towards The Alamo Square. Once, you reach Alamo Square, voila, you'll find Painted ladies on you right at Steiner St.
Show less

I will honestly say that there isn't much to the Painted Ladies but if you grew up watching Full House, you won't care. I had to hop in an Uber and climb that damn hill just to see the exact angle at which the opening scene from Full House was filmed. I can say that it wasn't as vibrant as what I remember from the show and I didn't get the exact angle but it was still magical. I loved it. I would do it again. It was free and easy to do so, why not?
Show less
What a joy to go see the houses, my family wasn't particularly interested, but honored me for the stop. Beautiful homes & park, so glad I made it a priority!

We were headed to Golden Gate Park so we made a side trip to find the six houses. They were pretty average houses not nearly as bright as I expected them to be, not really worth the time or effort to find them.

Well the painted ladies are worth the drive for the scenery. Alamo Park across the street is nice for a quick walk and there is a fun playground for kids to play. HOWEVER your car will likely get broken into (as ours did and I have read other reviews that have had this happen). We had a small picnic lunch bag they took. So maybe just drive it if you don't want to deal with insurance issues. Police don't come out for smash & grabs. They make you dial 311 to file a report. Good luck.
Show less
Worth exploring more of the ladies

The story and inhabitant of this houses is quite interesting, but the overall story of how the western addition came to be, even more. You will find equally or more beautiful Victorian homes scattered around the city, some actually moved there when the area was deemed needing a "renovation" that just happened to chase the poor to benefit the rich. The setting in front of the park is spectacular
Show less
The park was pretty crowded and hard to find a parking spot, but totally worth the effort. My sister and I are big Full House fans so this was the perfect end to our San Francisco trip.
Waste of time. They're not even that cool

My husband says they're neat because there was so much craftsmanship that went into these cookie-cutter homes. I wasn't, however, as impressed. The park across from the Painted Ladies was filled with a bunch of pot-smokers waiting for the 4th of July fireworks when we visited. I think it was a waste of time, but maybe if I knew more about them or their history I would think it a cooler experience.
Show less
Worth a quick stop if you're in the area

On a recent trip with my sisters to San Francisco, we headed for the painted ladies, down near Alamo Park. We admired the intricate detail work on these beautiful Victorian-style houses while humming the Full House theme song. We also walked around Alamo Park a bit, as there are interesting houses to see on every side.

Worth a quick stop if you're in the area. Better on a pretty day, as you're outside on a wind-swept hill.
Show less
Unique and fun wine tour. Love the VW vans. Highly recommend. They went above and beyond to make sure we had an awesome time!!
Sat in the park and gazed at the Painted Ladies as well as other homes in the neighborhood. The detailing is exquisite.
Spectacular sight of old and new San Francisco
Worth taking a look at to get some spectacular views of the modern skyscraper bearing San Francisco with the beautiful painted ladies houses in the foreground.

I think this is better than some of the more touristy spots like fishermans wharf or pier 39. The views are amazing and it's actually a pretty tranquil spot. If you have kids with you there is a nice playground with views of the painted ladies and the city. It's really clean to especially compared to some of the more touristy locations. Check it out if it's close, I wouldn't spend a lot of time getting there however.
Show less

Nice little park nearby with a great view of the city on a clear day. Worth a short stop. Its great for a family with kids as there is a gated playground. The houses themselves are interesting and very photogenic.

We were stopping over to take the very touristy picture of the painted ladies but ended up staying for a while so the kids could play on the playground in Alamo square. Alamo square is very nice and peaceful. It was a good way to spend 30 minutes and let the kids just be kids for a bit.
Show less

We aren't really the picnicking type and my husband didn't really have a strong opinion either way about seeing the houses, so we stopped by in our uber while we were on our way to another destination so I could pop-out and take a few pictures for sentimental value (#fullhousefans). Iconic view of the houses for those who recognize them from TV and movie scenes.

Alamo park seems nice and is no longer under construction so maybe a nice picnic spot.
Show less

These beautiful homes are displayed in the opening credits of the tv series Full House. Some people think one of these houses is the home used in the show. The actual Full House Home is on a different street.

These homes are directly across from the Alamo Square (a park).

Here are some tips to consider:
1. Parking is free all around the park if you can find a spot.
2. The best picture taking is on the Alamo Square on top of the hill directly in front of the Painted Ladies.
3. Nearest public restroom is at Alamo Square facing the Painted ladies.
Show less
We visited around 11am and got some great photos from the park opposite with the city background in the back drop. Put simply these are a must when in San Francisco!

You have to go to Alamo Square to see the Painted Ladies and there is nothing else to see or go close to this Square but the visit is worth it. There are people living in these houses but you can approach them.

Went there today with the kids to take a pic in front of the Painted Ladies and to use the washroom at Alamo Square. They don't make it easy to find parking-blocked off for the most part. Managed to find a spot. Was there for 10 min. Washrooms were disgusting. Park was great and Painted Ladies and their SF city backdrop was beautiful. Great photo ops for Full House fans. Like I said, 10 min later, went back to our car and the back windshield was smashed. Stolen were 3 of our backpacks-thank God I had our passports on me. Noticed shards of broken glass along the same street. Read reviews that this has happened to many others. Why aren't police patrolling this area? No police were in site. We hung around and tried to get through on the phone- no luck. Drove to Richmond Police station to file a report. What an upsetting way to finish off an otherwise great visit from Toronto. Although the weather and many parts of the city are great, it was a reminder of the crime issue and massive homeless/drug problems that exist. I wish better precautions would be taken by law enforcement considering this is a very common problem tourists encounter in the city. Please protect your tourists San Francisco!
Show less

We parked on the street and got out of our car for 10 minutes to snap a photo of the infamous painted ladies. When we came back, someone broke our car window and stole two bags from the car. Two other cars were broken into around us. After walking around the park, we realized this happens ALL the time. Broken glass lined the street. There is a police station 2 blocks away, yet, don't do more to prevent crime. They stole our child's backpack with his baby blanket. Very unfortunate.
Show less
Beautiful reminders is San Francisco past

They don't build them like this today, but the Painted Ladies are beautiful reminders of San Francisco's past and the way that San Francisco meshes its past with the scant garde.

Things like this don't just happen. Credit to those who replaced the old Navy Gray paint once popular because it was cheap. The paint and blend of color is a pleasure to the eye.
Show less
Not worth the trip unless you really enjoyed Full House

While esthetically pleasant, stopping by to see these houses is not worth the trip. It was more entertaining to watch the hundreds of people sitting in the adjacent park mesmerized by the houses. I guess if you are a super fan of Full House it's ok. Otherwise spend your time elsewhere.
Show less

WE went in April and the whole Alamo Square opposite was closed to renovations so it was disappointing we could't sit in the park and enjoy the view. The houses and street was amazing though. Not easy to get to go either by public transport.
Gorgeous homes in a beautiful neighborhood. Unlike any other

We went to see the Painted Ladies during a recent trip to San Francisco and felt it was worth the drive. The homes were beautiful and the other homes in the neighborhood were equally as exquisite. We felt it was worth the drive. I have included a photo.
Show less
Only architecture lovers will like this

It's very hilly in this area so it was hard for my mom to hike up the hill to get a good view of the city over the rooftops. The alamo square park was closed due to remodeling and an upcoming event but they left a small corner for people to go to look. Most of the houses surrounding that whole park were very beautiful. I walked almost all the way around the park and admired each house I saw. There were a few shops a couple blocks away along with a few restaurants. Very nice area.
Show less
I expected to get to the hill take a couple pictures and then head out. But it is actually an awesome view all around, especially the painted ladies with skyline in background. Grab a seat and enjoy.

This is definitely a must-see especially in great weather! When I visited in November 2016, the park in front of the Painted Ladies was closed for renovation. Check before you go if the park is open because that's the best place you can take photos and enjoy the view.
Show less
Quick ride on the city bus to catch a picture. A must do in San Francisco! Some construction in the park, but still able to get a great view.
There are only a handful of victorian houses to see at the address mentioned. I did not really find it worth a great deal.

The Painted Ladies (aka the Full House) are pretty self explanatory. At this time the Alamo park is under construction or some minor remodeling, but one can still take advantage of the view. I'd imagine that when the park is not under construction that people gather around and have picnics as this would be the perfect place to do so.
Show less

Nice little park in front of the houses. Houses in beautiful colors. San Francisco is definitely a place one should go visit on their bucket list! Food is Excellent! Such a variety of it! I lived in San Francisco years ago and this was one place I made sure to see.
Show less
here's another free sight to take advantage of. Cool architecture, iconic photo-ops, nice park to relax in (it was closed when we were there). And the houses around the block are cool too.
Iconic view but nothing more than a photo

Whilst the houses are lovely you will only spend a few minutes here unless you take advantage of the green area up the road (looking down onto the houses). Here you can sit and take in the vista. They are beautifully painted and upkept and make a nice picture but not a lot more to see here. Best to do this as a stop off - perhaps if taking a bus tour or on the way to something else.
Show less
What a cuties this Ladies!!! Small houses painted in beautiful colors, in Steiner Street, near Alamo Square. Beatiful view of the city, with skyscrapers on the back.

One of those iconic views that need to be seen as part of a visit to SF, easy to reach by bus, and there is a large park opposite from which to view and photograph the buildings without upsetting the occupants.

Won't take long to visit but definitely worth including on any planned visit to the city
Show less
You've seen these Painted Ladies everywhere through the years. Postcards, posters, stationary, Movies, commercials, on and on. But if you have a chance to see them in person, now that's the best!
A classic site but work on the park limited the view. A quick visit to these grand old houses is worth it. to admire the great architecture of these unique houses. Its a quick drive from downtown
Just go see it! Cool view of the bay from the park.

I will admit, the main reason motivating my visit was the fact I was a Full House fan as a kid, but the houses are beautiful. Do a little research on them before going and you'll find it even more enjoyable when you get there. Lots of history. Don't let any snark guy walking by tell you any different. ; )
Show less

These beautiful old buildings are well maintained Victorian houses, colorfully painted and make a pretty picture against the back drop of San Francisco. Easy to get to by pubic transport or drive to. An iconic spot to take photos.

This is one of the main attractions in San Francisco. Very easy to find. Having not seen the television show "Full House", I didn't really see the fascination with this, apart from the buildings themselves.

Visiting the painted ladies was a "full house" nostalgia moment. It really wasn't much else. You can get a good view from the park across the street. However the park was closed when we visited so we could only stand on the edge of the hill. If you read about the houses they have a neat history. I wouldn't make this attraction a top one unless you were a fanatic of "full house"
Show less
If your in San Francisco this is one of the main attractions. Easy to find and the pretty little painted ladies are a lovely site to see. Great photo opportunity.
There are plenty of nice houses there. Perhaps it's the history behind it that makes it stand out. Great to take a tram ride or bus ride to go around the neighbourhood to explore the area.

I was never a fan of the Full House television series, but I seem to be in the minority. There was a ton of people taking pictures and selfies of this row of houses and it's sure to get worse once they have opened the park.

The park next to this row of homes is currently under construction and limits some of the foot traffic per the tour guide. However, there was a little patch of grass available for pictures of the houses and there had to have been 200 people taking pictures.

The houses and History were interesting, even if you are not a fan of the TV show. They were beautiful homes and neighborhood with some scenic views of the bays in the background.
Show less
The Painted Ladies of San Francisco

I had to come see the Painted Ladies while I was in San Francisco! Growing up as a fan of Full house (tv show) I always said to myself, "one day, when I make it to America I'm going to make sure I stop to see and appreciate the Ladies in all their glory!"
Show less
Nice architecture, beautifully painted. Something to see if your in the area. Not much time needed for viewing.
Typical San Francisco houses in different colours, climbing the street. Worth seeing, nice overview of San Francisco to.

If you're in the area, drive by. Not somewhere you need to plan into your vacation. Nothing to do here. Only cool for a couple of pictures and that's it. If you're passing by, stop and take some pictures, but there's not really a reason to go out of your way to see it. Google images has better views than tourists have access to.
Show less
Loved!! I grew up watching Full House, so seeing the ladies was a must! A quick 2 mile walk from the Omni Hotel, where we stayed!

Beautiful architecture and fun history of the Painted Ladies. All homes in the area are beautiful! The park was closed when we were there, but would be a great place to have a picnic and enjoy the surroundings.
A long way for a picture

It's exactly what you expect it to be. Worth seeing if you have a car or are in the area. Might have been nicer had the park across the street been open (it was completely fenced off for construction). You don't need more than a couple of minutes here.
Show less
There are LOTS of pretty houses in SF. There are just a few.

I remember seeing a few episodes of Full House back in the day, so it was fun to see the houses. That said, look around and you will see LOTS of houses of this same style that are beautifully painted. (Some of the park across the street is closed for renovations right now.)
Show less
Despite renovations in Alamo Square Park, still a nice view

During the time of our visit, the park ws undergoing a renovation, causing it to be closed. Fortunately, there was a viewing area where the Painted Ladies could be seen, against the backdrop of downtown San Francisco. Be aware that the renovation work will last until about mid-April 2017. The best time to see the painted ladies, is mid-afternoon, as the facades of the houses are in the shade in the morning
Show less

The Painted Ladies are beautiful, the Alamo park is under construction, but they have an area for people to take pictures, there is parking along the park, so you can just pull up, park and take pictures, a must see in San Francisco.
If You're Looking for The Tanner's

Like most teens, my daughters wanted to see the "Full House - House" while in SF. That's at 1709 Broderick Street. Set your GPS, and you can skip the rest of this attraction. That house is owned by the Fuller House production company, has a marker out front telling you which one, and is the famous front of the house we all know and love. There will be a crowd out front waiting to take their pictures on the steps. No organization or fee, so it's all reliant on good manners. To both each other and the surrounding REAL homes. No parking, so most just pull over as far as they can and put the hazards on, and the kids can jump out and get their pics as fast as possible. That's illegal of course, so make sure one remains behind the wheel to quickly move if necessary. Just drive around the block. Worth the effort for the unique photo-op!
Show less

I confess when my friend took me here I had no idea why we'd gone. I mean they were nice but we'd seen other gorgeous houses but as i stood on the hill I got it. The park was closed for work but as we walked along the path a car drove past blasting the Full House theme which was hilarious. It's worth going to see a piece of TV history.
Show less
It is a nice view of the houses. Doesn't take long and its free. Currently they are doing construction on the park across from the houses.

We were fortunate to get a pretty, sunny day. It was a bit traffic crowded along street to get the photos I'd like to have had but it was still a fun spot to see. The girls loved the iconic row houses.

They are beautiful houses an in the background one has a lovely view of the San Francisco skyline. Alamo Square features some of San Francisco's best preserved architecture. Unfortunately there has been an invasion of tour buses.

This was really disappointing. Changed my original plan to visit Haight Ashbury by Crissy Field, etc and went to this section instead to see the houses. Oops! Big mistake.

Yes, there were very nice houses with interesting and ornate construction. There were also a couple of good photo ops from the front of the closed small park. So after ten minutes of that, what next? Nothing. We wandered a bit and ended up at a neat little lunch spot for a beer, but it was a waste of an Uber to get there and back.

If you have a rental car, and want to drive by, have at it. Otherwise, see any of the other great things in San Francisco.
Show less
Cute homes, but not much going on

The few homes on this row have some amazing architecture, but it wasn't that exciting to me. We ended up walking another 20 min to find the Full House house and that was worth it to see. Much more fun for me than 4 random houses.
Show less
There's not a good way to get an unobstructed view right now due to the construction of the park across the street. Go re-enact the beginning of Full House, but the houses are just people's homes.

I am so glad we visited the painted ladies. I love Full House! And now Fuller House!!! We all relived the times when we watched the series as we sat at the park across the street. The park is under going construction so we couldn't sit right across the street but it was good enough. All I can say is it's beautiful and having a picnic across the street would have been perfect however we didn't have time to do that.
Show less
If killing time do a drive by. But no need to go out of your way unless it's a must see for you personally.

Beautiful and Iconic homes! You've seen them on TV and now it's time to see them in person! We were so blessed to meet one of the owners of these beautiful homes and get some of the history. It was really cool to see this popular scenery! Don't miss it if you can help it. It stunk that they were remodeling the park which was also made famous by the Full House sitcom. But still worth the visit! The bonus is that it's FREE!!!
Show less
Really beautiful houses. Be sure to take your camera with you. Finding a parking spot nearby can a bit difficult.
There are many more lovely houses in the city than these.

One of the many places we stopped at in 4 days in the city, and the one that least appealed to me and was our shortest stop, but M'Lady wanted to go, and we were on honeymoon so who am I to argue?

Ok, so now the good bits, these houses are very iconic and have a history & background which is worth finding out about (we listened in to a tour guide). They also cost stupidly large amounts of money if they come up for sale. Unfortunately the park opposite was under renovation, so we didn't have anywhere to sit and enjoy the view.

Chances are you may well have seen then in a film or TV program based in the city at some point. They tend not to show the apartment block next door though!

Personally this is one row of houses I wouldn't want to live in, never mind the prices but too many damned tourists, including one couple having a photo-shoot on the steps of one of them.

However, there are very many beautiful houses in the city (including just a few door up the hill) and having had a wander around on my own 5 years ago, I did find these a bit boring in comparison. They are also very similar in design.

But, if you are on a tour that takes them in, then great, but I wouldn't go out of my way to see them again.
Show less

We really think the Painted Ladies are wonderful. Located across from Alamo Square (ongoing construction in park), the Painted Ladies are a row of seven colorful, Queen Anne-style, Victorian houses. All are private homes and not available for touring but the exteriors are truly awesome. Among the architectural features, they all include beautifully intricate stained-glass windows, bay windows & gingerbread gables. Great visit just wandering down the street and closely inspecting the exterior of each house.
Show less

These houses are the typical icons of San Francisco. Seen in numerous movies. We made the walk up the hill to the park overlooking the Painted Ladies and they are beautiful. They are a must see if you visit San Francisco
Love the houses, park was under renovation so couldn't sit and view, not as vivid as I thought, but still nice to visit.

The houses are quite nice, and I realize it was a touristy thing to do, but who doesn't love full house nostalgia. However, the park across the street which gives you a good vantage point for pictures, is closed and you really can't get a good picture or look of the city behind them. It was underwhelming anyway.
Show less
Nice unique place to go and see
One of those things that each city has that you should go and see and the Painted Ladies is one of them. Yes its just houses but there is a nice park opposite them to take in the view of the city.
Part of San Francisco's History and Charm

This is really a drive-by attraction, but worth experiencing at least once, like Lombard Street. None of the Ladies are open for tours as they are all private homes. Alamo Square Park is right across the street where you can sit to take in their beauty and contemplates SF life during that era. If you are a "Full House" fan, the fictional Tanner Family lived near by (about 1 mile away) at 1709 Broadrick. My 17-year old granddaughter loved finding the Tanner house.
Show less
The only reason people cum here is because of the Full House tv program. Not much to do once you have seen them
One of the most beutiful and well keep neighborhoods in United States. You may have to search around for parking, but is totally worth it.

It was great to see the Victorian houses and the setup was absolutely great

I fact housing around the entire block for really nice and pleasant. All houses look awesome and are very well maintained

I have traveled a lot to Europe in the past and it did give u the European feel
Show less
We drove to the park across the street from The Painted Ladies. Girls loved this! Very lovely with San Francisco back drop. Kids got lots of selfies here. Enjoy!
Really cool to see. Just like in the movies. Really busy though. These are actually people's homes which is crazy. Don't need any forward planning you can just show up
Beautiful, colorful homes. If you have the time, take an early morning walk here for a quick view. Postcard views indeed. But it is not a must-see place
This is one busy street to see these beautiful homes. Be careful with the huge RVs trying to park to come see this. Too many tourists
Don't waste an uber or cab fare

Underwhelmed to say the least. If I'd have walked there I'd probably just be disappointed but we were too far away so took an uber. We were expecting this amazing street on a hill with beautifully painted houses. It's a little street with a small number of painted houses!! There are loads of similar design houses across SF and some painted ones as well. Just walk round some of the neighbourhoods you are near unless you are close enough to walk.
Show less
It was inconvenient to get there, had nothing else nearby to do, and just wasn't much to look at. It might be more worthwhile if you are driving a car instead of taking the bus.

It is just like the movies seeing this! Alamo Park - across the street - is currently under construction/renovation - so it makes it a little difficult to take pictures, but it still can be done. Very cool to see these homes in person - they are beautiful. While you're there, take a look at the other homes in the area. The architecture is gorgeous. Please note, these are near the top of the hill - so you will have to walk UP from wherever you're coming....
Show less

We were so disappointed to visit the Painted Ladies and see the entire park across the street all gated up and under construction. The whole point of visiting this area is to 1) get an awesome photo of the houses with the city in the background, and 2) visit the park that's featured during the opening credits of Full House. Well right now you can't do either. The sign said it would be done by winter 2016 and to be honest, there didn't look like much was going on behind the fences anymore. I'm not sure why people are denied access to the entire park!!! Our only option was to take photos up close just across the street. But it was garbage pickup day so the houses all had a few big garbage cans out front and there were trucks parked in front. All around a disappointing part of our trip that we were really looking forward to.
Show less

If you can come back to San Francisco I would wait to see the Painted Ladies later as the park across the street (the one they show in Full House) is currently under construction and the pictures came out with the construction fence. Other than that it will be a lovely tourist attraction once it's finished.
Show less
OK, not a must, there are nicer

First of all I must warn travelers that Alamo Sq is under renovation currently, there's a fence around and only a small part is left for catching these 7 ladies.
Second, if you came only for houses, there are far more beautiful around SF (N and S of Haight St specially).
Best thing about the Ladies is the contrast panorama with modern SF downtown high rises in the background.
Show less
You can't go to San Francisco and not see what most people know as the Full House house. There are beautiful!
Went for walk from UN plaza to painted ladies. It is five houses in Victorian architectures. Each house is painted in own colour and there are minor differences in external details.

To get here. Cute to see if you're in the neighbourhood, but there are some incredibly beautiful homes around the city. It's the 'houses plus city' backdrop that makes it picturesque so best on a sunny day.

The Painted Ladies are just in a normal neighborhood in San Francisco. Use Uber or walk to get there; the hills are tough, but there are park benches in Alamo Square to rest and enjoy the view of the homes, and of the city beyond.

This is a quick stop on a tour of San Francisco. The park beside the houses is currently undergoing renovations so there isn't much green space where to sit and enjoy the view. There is a nice view of the city beyond the Painted Ladies. The houses are definitely cute and picturesque and worth a quick stop.
Show less

Iconic local attraction. The park across the street is temporarily closed which would have made for some great photos. Plenty of tourists snapping pics , even going onto the steps of these homes. I don't recommend it, people actually live in these homes. Not much else in the area .
Show less
Great for a quick drive by!

My boys and I had just started watching the new fuller house on Netflix, so while in San Fran I knew this would be fun to see. The park across the street was under construction so it was tough to find parking and there were no bathrooms to use (check progress before going). It's not a long activity by Amy means but still a great drive by and worth a quick picture. You will be surrounded by other tourists doing exactly that.
Show less
Not What it is cracked up to be

We thought this was a "must see" in San Franciso. It is not. Pictures make the Painted Ladies look like they are across from a huge park when the park is really small. Houses looked nice, but not really that special
We rented a car on a business trip and specifically drove past the painted ladies. Really enjoyed seeing these old houses being taken care of so well!
Worth the visit these ladies are. Like most attractions in San Francisco make sure you use Uber or make some form of transportation to get there!

Tour was great but what really made it special and unique was the custom music track that matched the stops- from Otis Redding to Hendrix. There are stories behind every stop and track. This is a must for your trip!
Best way to get acquainted with SAN Fran

What a wonderful experience. Driving around with Antoine in his 1973 BW wagon was a unique way of learning about SF. He dove through all the main areas of the city and provided excellent info. He stopped at several locations for photos as well. Just a great time was had by all.
Show less

House numbers 710ish on the street are the main spot and are truly beautiful if you pay attention to the architectural details of the Victorian/Edwardian houses. Really though thousands of these houses were built during the period so even during a business ride around/through the area, keep your eye out for several beautiful examples of the period.
Show less
The most popular Victorians in the City

The ‘Painted Ladies’ are the most popularly colored residential Victorian houses you will see in your tour through the city. Go to any souvenir shop around the city and you are likely to see a photo and postcards of these Victorians along with other popular tourist attraction photos of Golden Gate Bridge, Fisherman’s Wharf, Cable cars, antique Street cars, Coit Tower and more.

These ‘Ladies’ have been depicted in movies from Mrs. Doubtfire, Invasion of the Body Snatchers, to TV series Full House. A postcard sent from the city is not complete without one from postcard row of the Painted Ladies.
Show less

The Painted Ladies highlight some of the nice architecture in the area around Alamo Square, but are not the only houses like this in the area.

When we were there in November they were doing work on the square so you could not enter all of it, but you can still get good photos of the painted ladies.
Show less

The buildings are beautiful and it boasts magnificent architecture. Its a great tourist spot and a must see if you are in San Francisco as it's the epitome of the neighbourhood. When we went, the far west house was under construction so it hinders the beauty of the other painted ladies building. Parking is very limited around the area as well.
Show less
Painted Ladies is a must see if you enjoy houses looking their finest! These ladies are all dolled up and are purely fun to view!
The area around Alamo Square is nice, but the Painted Ladies really are no more beautiful than the others in the area

We walked around the area of Alamo Square - there are some great buildings and cafés and playgrounds. The Painted Ladies houses really don't look much different than many of the other houses in the area.
The walk along the street was a lovely stroll and the houses were very pretty. There are some nice pictures to be taken along here
